headline: U.S. Senate Candidates Mandel, Gibbons Seen Going Toe to Toe at Debate
author: Aila Slisco
sentences: Recent polling indicates that Mandel, a former Ohio state treasurer who was an early frontrunner for the GOP nomination, has recently been overtaken by Gibbons, an investment banker who vied for the state's other Senate seat in 2018.

The Republicans facing off for the Senate seat have nearly all attempted to win primary voters by painting themselves as strong supporters of former President Donald Trump, who has yet to endorse any candidate in the race.
The confrontation began when Mandel, who was seated as Gibbons walked across the stage while speaking, accused the frontrunner of making "millions of dollars" from questionable investments in China.
A Fox News poll released earlier this month showed Gibbons with a 2 point lead over Mandel, while Gibbons had a 7 point lead in a poll from The Hill and Emerson College late last month.
Republican candidates Mike Gibbons and Josh Mandel went toe to toe during a debate organized by the conservative group FreedomWorks in Gahanna, Ohio, on Friday.
Last month, Mandel was featured in a viral video that showed him arguing with an audience member about "Black Lives Matter" activists at a different debate.
Gibbons angrily denied the accusation and said that Mandel "may not understand" because he had "never been in the private sector."
Two Republican candidates vying for an Ohio U.S. Senate seat engaged in an onstage confrontation that nearly became physical.
Mandel briefly backed off before again approaching Gibbons and repeating his history of military service.
Mandel became visibly upset and rose to his feet to approach Gibbons, coming within inches of his face.
"I like almost all of them, and it's hard not to," Trump told The Washington Examiner this week.
The heated exchange ended when the moderator finally convinced Mandel to return to his seat.
Don't tell me I haven't worked," Mandel said while pointing a finger at his rival.
The debate moderator then approached the two men and attempted to separate them.
Vance could be seen smirking while seated as his opponents nearly came to blows.
My hardest thing is to endorse people over others when they all like you."
A RealClearPolitics average shows Gibbons with a narrow 1.3 percent lead.
The crowd began to boo as the men remained within inches of each other.

"Guys, sit down," Vance said after briefly rising from his seat.
